docs.abstract: As the spread of the coronavirus threatens the Games, a whole ecosystem surrounding the world’s largest sporting event is stuck in a holding pattern.
docs.snippet: As the spread of the coronavirus threatens the Games, a whole ecosystem surrounding the world’s largest sporting event is stuck in a holding pattern.
docs.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Toshiya Fujita just wants somebody to make a decision already.

headline.main: Will the Olympics Go On? Japan’s Businesses Would Like to Know

byline.original: By Motoko Rich and Ben Dooley

docs.abstract: There is little doubt that a severe economic downturn awaits. How bad it gets depends on the nature of the government response.
docs.snippet: There is little doubt that a severe economic downturn awaits. How bad it gets depends on the nature of the government response.
docs.lead_paragraph: Want this email in your inbox each morning? Sign up here.

headline.main: The Coronavirus Bailouts Begin to Take Shape

docs.abstract: Bailouts of companies or industries just cause division. The answer: a government “bridge loan” to everyone.
docs.snippet: Bailouts of companies or industries just cause division. The answer: a government “bridge loan” to everyone.
docs.lead_paragraph: The Covid-19 crisis will take time to be solved by science. The economic crisis can be solved right now.

headline.main: This Is the Only Way to End the Coronavirus Financial Panic
headline.print_headline: How to Hold A Job Open For Everyone

docs.abstract: Some chains have remained open during the pandemic, worrying employees who have to travel to their jobs and then interact with the public.
docs.snippet: Some chains have remained open during the pandemic, worrying employees who have to travel to their jobs and then interact with the public.
docs.lead_paragraph: The Macy’s in Manhattan’s Herald Square opened its doors to customers at 10 a.m. on Tuesday, as planned.

headline.main: Plight of Retail Workers: ‘I’m Scared to Go to Work’

byline.original: By Sapna Maheshwari and Michael Corkery

docs.abstract: A new surge of bond purchases is intended to counteract “serious risks” to the eurozone economy as investors start to doubt Italy’s creditworthiness.
docs.snippet: A new surge of bond purchases is intended to counteract “serious risks” to the eurozone economy as investors start to doubt Italy’s creditworthiness.
docs.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — The European Central Bank will begin an enormous new wave of bond purchases meant to counteract the “serious risks” to the eurozone caused by the coronavirus pandemic.

headline.main: Europe’s Central Bank Vastly Expands Stimulus Measures
headline.print_headline: Declaring ‘No Limits,’ European Central Bank Expands Stimulus

docs.abstract: Our photographer spent the last two weeks capturing the increasing fragility of New York.
docs.snippet: Our photographer spent the last two weeks capturing the increasing fragility of New York.
docs.lead_paragraph: New York was still making money a week ago. A few people wearing masks, some closings, but generally business as usual. And then we tumbled down a cliff. By Friday, commuters arriving at Grand Central Terminal paused as they entered the main concourse — stunned by its emptiness, the usual din quieted by stay-at-home orders from companies and the government. For the first time, the vast, star-covered ceiling seemed appropriate.

headline.main: Witnessing the Birth of the Coronavirus Economy

docs.abstract: “It’s just shocking,” one bean supplier said. “I used to be the loneliest man at the farmer’s market.”
docs.snippet: “It’s just shocking,” one bean supplier said. “I used to be the loneliest man at the farmer’s market.”
docs.lead_paragraph: Tim McGreevy has worked in the bean business for more than 30 years. But when he scanned the bean aisles at a grocery store in Pullman, Wash., on Sunday, he saw something he had never seen before: empty shelves.

headline.main: A Boom Time for the Bean Industry
headline.print_headline: Suddenly, the Lowly Bean Is a Coveted Pantry Item

docs.abstract: Live updates on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
docs.snippet: Live updates on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
docs.lead_paragraph: This briefing is no longer updating. Read the latest developments in the coronavirus outbreak here.

headline.main: U.S. Stock Futures Sink as Washington Struggles Over Rescue Plan

docs.abstract: Work on residential and commercial projects is slowing as materials from overseas become harder to get, posing a threat to construction jobs.
docs.snippet: Work on residential and commercial projects is slowing as materials from overseas become harder to get, posing a threat to construction jobs.
docs.lead_paragraph: When it comes to obtaining building materials, real estate developers often buy globally, not locally. But as the coronavirus spreads across the world, bringing countries to a standstill, the lack of access to overseas supplies is sending jitters through the construction industry.

headline.main: Chinese Copper, Italian Marble: Coronavirus Shipping Delays Hurt Developers
headline.print_headline: Builders Shudder as Imported Materials Idle

docs.abstract: Technology from Amazon, Apple, Google, IBM and Microsoft misidentified 35 percent of words from people who were black. White people fared much better.
docs.snippet: Technology from Amazon, Apple, Google, IBM and Microsoft misidentified 35 percent of words from people who were black. White people fared much better.
docs.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — With an iPhone, you can dictate a text message. Put Amazon’s Alexa on your coffee table, and you can request a song from across the room.

headline.main: There Is a Racial Divide in Speech-Recognition Systems, Researchers Say
headline.print_headline: When Data Lacks Diversity, Black Voices Are Muffled
